These mononuclear components of the intestinal mucosal immune system interact with the epithelial cells in a complex fashion. Intestinal epithelial cells have been shown to express various cytokines including tumor necrosis factor a (TNF-a), IL-1, IL-8, IL-10, monocyte chemotactic protein 1, and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, either constitutively 1 or in response to stimuli such as TNF-a, IL-1, viruses, 14 or invasive bacteria.2 Furthermore, intestinal epithelial cells have been shown to exhibit various physiological or phenotypic responses to a variety of cytokines including TNF-a, IFN-g, IL-1, IL-4, and IL-6.3,4,13  Thus, cytokines can function as local autocrine or paracrine regulators of both mucosal and immune function.
